question: What resources need to be manually cleaned up after terminating the Service Catalog product for EBS volume encryption?
RAGAS_context:
[" NORMAL All non-encrypted EBS volumes attached to the instances can be encrypted The encryption operations will be done on all EBS volumes EXCLUDE All EBS volumes attached to the instance are already encrypted. No operation needed. WARNING PARTIAL SOME EBS volumes attached to the instance cannot be encrypted. Check the EBS volumes details in the logs for more explanations. The encryption operations will be done on EBS volume which can be encrypted WARNING EXCLUDE ALL EBS volumes attached to the instance cannot be encrypted. Check the EBS volumes details in the logs for more explanations. The EBS encryption operations can't be executed

Cleaning

When you don't need anymore to execute the encrypt operation, just Terminate the product from Provisioned products list, into Service Catalog console.

When you terminate the product, the following resources are deleted:

All resources created by the product (Lambda functions, Step Functions, IAM Roles, ...)

Lambda functions log stream.

For the other resources, the cleaning will be done automatically after a retention period or in some cases, you need to do cleaning by your own:

Log streams into operation log group are not deleted. They will be automatically cleaned up at the end of the specified retention period (default = 30 days).

AMI (and so snapshots) used as backup during the operation. To automatically clean it, the DeleteOn tag is setup on AMIs. By default, an AMI is deleted after 30 days.

:::caution

As the automated AMI clean up is not deployed by default in Lab accounts, no cleaning will be done.

:::

Old non-encrypted EBS Volumes. If, into the product's parameters, you decided to not delete them, those volumes will remain and will never be automatically deleted. You will have to delete them manually yourself. To help you to spot them, the following tags can be looked up in the EBS console, via CLI or API:

Tag Value EBSEncryption/status done EBSEncryption/newVolume id of newly created volume"]
ground_truth: The resources that need to be manually cleaned up after terminating the Service Catalog product for EBS volume encryption are the old non-encrypted EBS volumes, if the option to not delete them was chosen in the product's parameters. These volumes will remain and will never be automatically deleted, so they need to be deleted manually by looking up the tags 'EBSEncryption/status' with value 'done' and 'EBSEncryption/newVolume' with the ID of the newly created volume. AMI (and so snapshots) used in backup are not deleted by default in Lab accounts as the automated AMI clean up is not deployed. Moreover, log streams into operation log group are not deleted but will be automatically cleaned up at the end of the specified retention period (default = 30 days).

:::info

Note we will use LZI word above to designate the AWS Landing Zone (i.e. Landing Zone Infrastructure)

In the worse case, it can be the loss of an entire AWS Data center. It is the main risk we have with a long term impact. In other word, it the risk we must absolutely cover. - Main HUB region Trouble/Lost = Troubles consideration related to the Main region use by the LZI. You can find list of Main LZI regions here. - Other region Trouble/Lost = Troubles consideration related to the other regions than Main region use by the LZI. - Services Used = Main services used for this component of LZI. This section provides instructions on how to use NinGines to catch incidents and trigger appropriate automation in the GitLab pipeline, enabling you to update the ticket status according to the status of the automation.

How to start

Request your NinGines GitLab project following the Quick start.

Read this documentation. :bookmark_tabs:

Follow the prerequisites and the branch strategy.

Update your dictionary.

Submit your MMS item in MMS DEV to get variables and play with dev.variables file.

Develop your automation. :rocket:

Triggers

:::info NinGines Core fetches Incident items every 5 minutes in all MMS environments. :::

:::tip The MMS Incident structure is under the responsibility of your team. For further information, reach out to teams managing automatic incident creation, like Splunk or Prisma Teams. :::

Dictionary

Dictionaries permit to match MMS items with NinGines pipelines. In your GitLab project you'll find a dictionary file in dictionaries folder. Here is the dictionary structure for the Incident items:

Description

incident_short_description: MMS incident short description.

autom_name: Automation name.

enabled: true or false.

comment: Comment for your personal use.

:::note - A dictionary is only for one assignment group. - Multiple dictionaries are supported. ['IAM User Access Key Management

Overview

The purpose of this automation is to avoid to have IAM User access keys remain active when it is not used or when it is expired. It is the operational enforcement of Air Liquide Cloud security policies.

IAM User access keys are considered as inactive when showing no activity in the past 40 days.

IAM User access keys are considered as expired 365 days after creation (ie. IAM User access keys must be rotated before they reach 365 days of age.)

Architecture

Automation sequence

Scope

This automation is executed: - into all Essential and Managed accounts - for all existing IAM Users

Are excluded from the automation: - Lab Accounts - The AWS environments managed by Claranet for the HDS scope in Europe

Are deactivated: - Keys not used from at least 40 days. - Keys created from at least 365 days.

A deactivated key still appears in the IAM User Access Keys list but is not usable.

Are deleted: - For expired keys: Keys deactivated 31 days ago, even if keys is reactivated in the meantime. So when the age of the key is 396 days old. - For non used keys: Keys deactivated 31 days ago except if key is reactivated and used again. So if key is not used for 71 days.

Schedule

This automation is scheduled once a day, between 12h-13h UTC globally.

How it works

Automation proceeds as follows: - List all IAM User access keys deployed in the AWS account - For each key in the list: - Check for how many days key is not used - Check for how many days key was created - If key is not used for almost 40 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is not used for more than 40 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is created for almost 365 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is created for more that 365 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account (even if the key is used) - If key was deactivated for the first time 31 days ago: delete it

:::tip

The automation will use the AWS API to deactivate or delete keys. If you have deployed it via CloudFormation, Terraform, etc. you may have a drift from your corresponding stack.

:::

How to

How to configure the recipients of the warning emails

To be informed about events regarding your IAM User Access Keys (near expiration, deactivation, etc...), you can specify the recipients of the warning emails. Use the following available tags:

Tag Key Value gio:iamUser:owner A space separated list of up to 5 IAM User owner e-mail addresses → To recipients of mails. gio:iamUser:cc A space separated list of up to 5 IAM User owner e-mail addresses → Cc recipients of mails.

:::caution

The tags are case sensitive

:::

:::info

You can find more detailed information regarding IAM Users here.

:::

How to deploy a compliant IAM User

You may use the self-service solution "IAM Users" which deploys a simple IAM User compliant with cloud and Air Liquide security standards.

Get Started with IAM User deployment

FAQ

Why do we deactivate expired keys? An IAM User access key is a secret credential that can be used to access internal Air Liquide IT resources. The older this credential is, the more we have a risk of having it stolen/compromised. This is why we have an Air Liquide security golden rule regarding the age of those keys and the obligation to change/rotate it at least once a year.

How can I prevent this deactivation? By respecting the Air Liquide security policy, so changing/rotating your keys once a year no deactivation will occur as your keys will not reach the maximum time life of 1 year.

What is the impact of this automatic deactivation? After deactivation of IAM User access key, the key is no longer usable. If you have a workload which uses the key, this workload will stop working just after deactivation.

Will I receive a notification? If you are the AWS account owner, or if you are the IAM User owner, you will receive a mail to inform you about the deactivation with the reference of the deactivated key.

I own an IAM User. Why am I not receiving any mail? It means the tags on IAM Users are not properly set up with your email address.']

The following email notifications are sent as part of the automation process for managing IAM User access keys:

1. Warning email sent to the owner of the key and the owner of the AWS account when a key is not used for almost 40 days.

question: What key lifecycle events trigger notifications & actions in the IAM User key automation?
RAGAS_context:
['IAM User Access Key Management

Overview

The purpose of this automation is to avoid to have IAM User access keys remain active when it is not used or when it is expired. It is the operational enforcement of Air Liquide Cloud security policies.

IAM User access keys are considered as inactive when showing no activity in the past 40 days.

IAM User access keys are considered as expired 365 days after creation (ie. IAM User access keys must be rotated before they reach 365 days of age.)

Architecture

Automation sequence

Scope

This automation is executed: - into all Essential and Managed accounts - for all existing IAM Users

Are excluded from the automation: - Lab Accounts - The AWS environments managed by Claranet for the HDS scope in Europe

Are deactivated: - Keys not used from at least 40 days. - Keys created from at least 365 days.

A deactivated key still appears in the IAM User Access Keys list but is not usable.

Are deleted: - For expired keys: Keys deactivated 31 days ago, even if keys is reactivated in the meantime. So when the age of the key is 396 days old. - For non used keys: Keys deactivated 31 days ago except if key is reactivated and used again. So if key is not used for 71 days.

Schedule

This automation is scheduled once a day, between 12h-13h UTC globally.

How it works

Automation proceeds as follows: - List all IAM User access keys deployed in the AWS account - For each key in the list: - Check for how many days key is not used - Check for how many days key was created - If key is not used for almost 40 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is not used for more than 40 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is created for almost 365 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account - If key is created for more that 365 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account (even if the key is used) - If key was deactivated for the first time 31 days ago: delete it

:::tip

The automation will use the AWS API to deactivate or delete keys. If you have deployed it via CloudFormation, Terraform, etc. you may have a drift from your corresponding stack.

:::

How to

How to configure the recipients of the warning emails

To be informed about events regarding your IAM User Access Keys (near expiration, deactivation, etc...), you can specify the recipients of the warning emails. Use the following available tags:

Tag Key Value gio:iamUser:owner A space separated list of up to 5 IAM User owner e-mail addresses → To recipients of mails. gio:iamUser:cc A space separated list of up to 5 IAM User owner e-mail addresses → Cc recipients of mails.

:::caution

The tags are case sensitive

:::

:::info

You can find more detailed information regarding IAM Users here.

:::

How to deploy a compliant IAM User

You may use the self-service solution "IAM Users" which deploys a simple IAM User compliant with cloud and Air Liquide security standards.

Get Started with IAM User deployment

FAQ

Why do we deactivate expired keys? An IAM User access key is a secret credential that can be used to access internal Air Liquide IT resources. The older this credential is, the more we have a risk of having it stolen/compromised. This is why we have an Air Liquide security golden rule regarding the age of those keys and the obligation to change/rotate it at least once a year.

How can I prevent this deactivation? By respecting the Air Liquide security policy, so changing/rotating your keys once a year no deactivation will occur as your keys will not reach the maximum time life of 1 year.

What is the impact of this automatic deactivation? After deactivation of IAM User access key, the key is no longer usable. If you have a workload which uses the key, this workload will stop working just after deactivation.

Will I receive a notification? If you are the AWS account owner, or if you are the IAM User owner, you will receive a mail to inform you about the deactivation with the reference of the deactivated key.

I own an IAM User. Why am I not receiving any mail? It means the tags on IAM Users are not properly set up with your email address.', '

How it works

Automation proceeds as follows:
- List all IAM User access keys deployed in the AWS account
- For each key in the list:
  - Check for how many days key is not used
  - Check for how many days key was created
  - If key is not used for almost 40 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account
  - If key is not used for more than 40 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account
  - If key is created for almost 365 days: send a warning email to owner of key and owner of AWS account
  - If key is created for more that 365 days: deactivate the key and send an informational email to owner of key and owner of AWS account (**even if the key is used**)
  - If key was deactivated for the first time 31 days ago: delete it

:::tip

The automation will use the AWS API to deactivate or delete keys. If you have deployed it via CloudFormation, Terraform, etc. you may have a drift from your corresponding stack.

:::

']

Authorizations in GitLab

You need to understand how it has been created and how it works before using the GitLab as a service. Developers as well as managers and project managers should read this tutorial.

Overview

We provide a flexible structure for Groups GitLab, in which you can set your own organization.

:::info

GIO only defines and manages the Top Level of the Groups structure in GitLab and assigns Owners for each BIS/entity using the service. Underneath that level, each BIS is able to manage Groups and delegate permissions autonomously.

:::

Read through GitLab Permissions documentation for more information.

Groups and Roles

GIO creates and manages the top level Groups of the organization

BIS Group Owners assign roles to people to subgroups and projects

You can manage all subgroups and projects within the Groups that you can access as per the permissions that were given to you by your Owners

Top Level Groups: they reflect more or less the current BIS structure, with some adaptations. GIO will create them with you during the onboarding and after if necessary.

Sub-groups: they are set by you depending on your needs and constraints.

Roles

Admin: this role is reserved solely for GIO.

Owner: this user role has extended rights to manage all groups and sub-groups that he/she owns. Maintainer: this user role can create projects within a Group

['## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## Update your accounts Operations Contact details

In order to make it easier for you to have operational information about your account, we are requesting you to update the Operations contact details under Alternate Contacts of your account information.

Why update?

It is very important that you do this update:

You will receive important information from AWS (instance health status, certificates renewal, outages...)

GIO Cloud Services has stopped forwarding AWS operations emails starting February 1st, 2020 onwards.

:::warning

This information is used by Landing Zone automations to warn you about upcoming actions that will impact your resources. Make sure it is accurate and up to date to avoid missing these important notifications.

:::

Procedure

Log into your account with the federation access and using an admin profile

Go to the My Account section of the console ()

Modify the operations contact as shown below:

Click on the Edit button

Indicate a contact. It should be Distribution List. You must avoid to set a single person email.']
ground_truth: It is important to update the Operations contact details for Landing Zone automations warnings because this information is used to warn you about upcoming actions that will impact your resources. Ensuring the contact details are accurate and up to date will help you avoid missing these important notifications.

question: What's the process for getting a VPS, from request to catalog search?
RAGAS_context:
['## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## Virtual Private Server

How to request a VM ?

i.e request a(some) EC2(s) within this offer ?

Go directly to the the request Provisioning a Virtual Private Server

OR

Go into ServiceNow and then

"Request Catalog - Catalogs"

and search the request

GIO Services

Business Apps Foundations

Advanced Cloud Services

Provisioning a Virtual Private Server

How to request access to the VM ?

For a Windows Servers

A special tag gio:provision:option is set to autoGroupId.

During the provisioning of the VM, a dedicated Active Directory group will be created:

DGG_Cloud-Services_-_SM

where - is the ID of the AWS account in which the server has been provisoned. The account ID can be found in your request (it depends on the HUB and if it is for IT or OT): check the Account Id (not the account name) under "IT account" or "OT account" in the request. - is the IP address of the server in hexadecimal

You can use this request in the service catalog "Active Directory Add / remove Active Directory Groups Members" to request to add a user in an Active Directory Group.

Or you can find the request in Service Now catalog:

GIO Services

Business Apps Foundations

Identity & Access Management

Active Directory Add / remove Active Directory Groups Members

For a Linux Servers

You should use the request in Service Now service catalog "Manage access to unix/Linux servers - All HUBs" to request the ctr or the ctu access to the server.

Or you can find the request in Service Now catalog:

GIO Services

Business Apps Foundations

Hybrid Cloud

Iaas VM (Windows, Linux)

Manage access to unix/Linux servers - All HUBs']
ground_truth: To request a Virtual Private Server (VPS), you can either go directly to the request 'Provisioning a Virtual Private Server' or go to ServiceNow, then to 'Request Catalog - Catalogs' and search for the request 'Provisioning a Virtual Private Server'. For access to a Windows Server, a special tag 'gio:provision:option' is set to 'autoGroupId'. During the provisioning of the VM, a dedicated Active Directory group is created. You can use the request in the service catalog 'Active Directory Add / remove Active Directory Groups Members' to request to add a user in an Active Directory Group. For access to a Linux Server, you should use the request in ServiceNow service catalog 'Manage access to unix/Linux servers - All HUBs' to request the ctr or the ctu access to the server.

question: What's the process to adjust AWS Lab's monthly alert trigger?
RAGAS_context:
['## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## Alerting

Default Budget Alerts provided by GIO

GIO is providing you with standard tooling to be alerted when your consumption reaches a threshold that you define. When creating your AWS Account, we deploy a default Billing Alarm that is based on the monthly threshold (in USD) that you have indicated in the request. The alert is based on the CloudWatch Billing Alarm feature deployed in the us-east-1 region.

To receive email alerts you must have subscribed to the SNS Topic for this alarm. You should have received an email from Billing Alert (no-reply@sns.amazonaws.com via amazonses.com) similar to the one below. If not, please check your spam.

Click on Confirm Subscription. It will open a new window in your web browser indicating that you have successfully subscribed to the SNS topic.

You will now receive an email if your consumption during a given month reaches the billing alert threshold.

Modify the alarm threshold

If you wish to readjust the alarm threshold:

Log in to the AWS Console for your Lab Account

Switch to the us-east-1 region (billing alarm can only be set in the us-east-1 region)

Browse to the CloudWatch Console and click on Billing in the left pane

Select the alarm and in Actions select Modify

Set the new threshold amount and click “Save changes”']
ground_truth: To adjust the AWS Lab's monthly alert trigger, follow these steps: 1. Log in to the AWS Console for your Lab Account. 2. Switch to the us-east-1 region, as the billing alarm can only be set in this region. 3. Browse to the CloudWatch Console and click on Billing in the left pane. 4. Select the alarm and in Actions select Modify. 5. Set the new threshold amount and click 'Save changes'.

question: What does GCP Standard Support offer for cloud management, including tech assistance and optimization tips, and how to access it during French business hours via Google Cloud Console?
RAGAS_context:
["## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## ## Support

GIO Support

GIO Cloud Services Support for GCP Essential services is available during French business days, from 9 AM to 6 PM CET/CEST, including French Holidays. Please note that there is no specific Service Level Agreement (SLA) beyond these support hours. The support during these hours covers incidents of all priorities and is managed by Europe team to serve a worldwide scope.

GCP Standard Support

GCP Standard support is available for all project.

GCP Standard support experts are available for many types of requests regarding GCP services, architecture, etc.:

Technical Support Service: This is the actual service provided by the support team to help resolve technical problems. This could involve answering technical queries, providing guidance, or troubleshooting issues

Active assist recommendations: Receive recommendations and insights to help optimize your Google Cloud resources for cost, security, performance, and manageability.

Open a case to the GCP Standard Support from the Console

Sign in to the Google Cloud console Support page

Select the project for which you'd like to open a support case

Open Cases

Click Create case

Complete the required fields and submit the form

:::tip More info on how to manage support cases: https://cloud.google.com/support/docs/manage-cases :::"]
ground_truth: GCP Standard Support offers technical assistance through its Technical Support Service, which helps resolve technical problems by answering queries, providing guidance, and troubleshooting issues. It also provides Active Assist recommendations to optimize Google Cloud resources for cost, security, performance, and manageability. To access this support during French business hours via Google Cloud Console, sign in to the Google Cloud Console Support page, select the project for which you'd like to open a support case, click on 'Open Cases', then 'Create case', complete the required fields and submit the form. However, the context does not specify if this support is available during French business hours.
